subject: RE: [junit] failSame,. etc. will be public?
msgSnippet: The new Assert class throws the same exception as Java s assert keyword. Another reason for having the new Assert class is that it lives in the same package
messageBody:
The new Assert class throws the same exception as Java's assert keyword.
Another reason for having the new Assert class is that it lives in the same
package with the rest of the new JUnit classes. Because statics aren't
inherited, however, we have to duplicate the code to retain backwards
compatibility.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Stephen Smith
> Sent: Sunday, July 31, 2005 10:06 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] failSame,. etc. will be public?
>
> What benefit does org.junit.Assert provide, as opposed to
> junit.framework.Assert? Unless some new assertions are available -
> Assert#assertException or Assert#assertInstanceOf, for
> example - I don't
> think the introduction of a new class is justified on the basis of
> altering which Exception it uses to indicate a failed assertion.
>
> Elliotte Harold wrote:
> > Alexandru Popescu wrote:
> >
> >
> >>As far as I can tell I think that the new Assert class was
> created to remove the custom
> >>AssertionException and use the AssertionException provided
> since JDK1.4. From my point of view this
> >>is definitely a very good reason to have it.
> >
> >
> > OK. I can see that, but I think that's a very bad idea. A JUnit
> > assertion test failure is not at all the same thing as a
> Java language
> > assert failure. They are two different things and they should be
> > distinguishable. Failure to do that might cause unexpected
> problems with
> > various tools that interpret an AssertionError as meaning
> one thing when
> > JUnit makes it mean something different.
> >
>
